messages.subject: RE: [unschoolingbasics] Flip a penny Tuesday, for a huge experiment
messages.msgSnippet: Etymologically derived through Middle English from the Latin second-type conjugation verb stŭdērĕ , which means to direct one s zeal at ; hence a student
messages.messageBody:
Etymologically derived through Middle English from the Latin second-type conjugation verb "stŭdērĕ", which means "to direct one's zeal at"; hence a student is one who directs zeal at a subject. Therefore by the very definition we are the only ones who have students.

And as K-12 is only a level indicator like age is and the Earth is a community... I think this is a wonderful large scale activity that we (my son and I) do not have regular access to and I thank you who shared this with us.

-----Original Message-----
From: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com [mailto:unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Deb Lewis
Sent: Monday, January 16, 2006 4:33 PM
To: unschoolingbasics@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [unschoolingbasics] Flip a penny Tuesday, for a huge experiment

This isn't the K-12 community and we don't have students.

Deb Lewis



Yahoo! Groups Links

messages.subject: Flip a penny Tuesday, for a huge experiment
messages.msgSnippet: Greetings from The Franklin Institute! Please help us  spread the word in the K-12 community about this online event scheduled for  Tuesday, January 17. It s
messages.messageBody:
Greetings from The Franklin Institute!

Please help us spread the word in the K-12 community about this online
event scheduled for Tuesday, January 17. It's simple! It's quick! It's
fun! It's free!

Thanks!
Karen Elinich
--------------------------------------------------------

THE FRANKLIN INSTITUTE ONLINE
www.fi.edu/flip

Celebrate Ben Franklin's 300th Birthday!

A Penny Flipped is Science Learned

Tuesday, January 17, 2006

On January 17, 2006, students around the world will commemorate Benjamin
Franklin's 300th birthday by participating in a common scientific
enterprise.

Students around the world will flip a coin ten times and then enter their
data at The Franklin Institute Online, demonstrating the power of a single
coin when students around the world collectively engage in a common
scientific experiment to determine, once and for all, if "heads" or "tails"
occurs more frequently in coin flips.

www.fi.edu/flip

--------------------------------------------------
The Franklin Institute Science Museum
222 North 20th Street
Philadelphia, PA 19103
